regret is a choice. It's that choice which can lead to self scarring. That 
scare can be erased by acceptance. If we can accept that which we would 
have regretted, we can make better decisions, recognize a situation before 
it becomes a regrettable choice and avert it.

Those who regret, have problems with self-forgiveness and if you cannot 
forgive yourself for something, you have the potential of a dreary, sad, 
depressed life.﻿

comments.text:
+Aaron Cabe
The statement " All western languages and some eastern come from 
Proto-Indo-European, so yes germanic comes from Latin as well..." is just 
false. Being an Indo- or Proto-Indo-European language does not make a 
language a derivative of Latin. Latin is not the primordial Indo-European 
language but itself derives from the Italic languages of it's region. The 
Germanic languages are on a completely different branch of the 
Indo-European tree, and the differentiation between Italic and most of the 
other sub-sets of Indo and Proto-Indo-European were already fairly well 
defined by as early as 1500 BCE, and well before the formation of 
Latino-Faliscan or Archaic Latin.

Chinese fable time:


A man named Sei Weng owned a beautiful mare which was praised far and wide. 
One day this beautiful horse disappeared. The people of his village offered 
sympathy to Sei Weng for his great misfortune. Sei Weng said simply, 
"That's the way it is."

A few days later the lost mare returned, followed by a beautiful wild 
stallion. The village congratulated Sei Weng for his good fortune. He said, 
"That's the way it is."

Some time later, Sei Weng's only son, while riding the stallion, fell off 
and broke his leg. The village people once again expressed their sympathy 
at Sei Weng's misfortune. Sei Weng again said, "That's the way it is."

Soon thereafter, war broke out and all the young men of the village except 
Sei Weng's lame son were drafted and were killed in battle. The village 
people were amazed as Sei Weng's good luck. His son was the only young man 
left alive in the village. But Sei Weng kept his same attitude: despite all 
the turmoil, gains and losses, he gave the same reply, "That's the way it

comments.text:
+Goabnb94 Not true. It would still be a mistake. See, you're mistaking the 
word "Mistake" for "Accident", see, an accident means something that was 
not meant to happen, happened. You did not accidentaly get drunk, or 
accidentally do stupid shit. All of that was in your own free will, which 
is what makes it a mistake, since a mistake is something that you've done 
with your own free will, knowing what will happen, but it was wrong. For 
example, if you decided against going to see a movie and instead went to 
the beach, but it turns out that it was too cold to go to the beach, then 
going to the beach would be a mistake. Not an accident.
comments.author: Elia Meyer

comments.text:
+Chris Friend A mistake would be say, investing in a business you got told 
was "really good" but you lost your money. It is not a mistake if you 
knowingly do stupid shit which could very obviously come back to bite you. 
For example, it was not a "mistake" when Justin Bieber peed in a mop bucket 
in that kitchen. He knew what he was doing, he knew it was illegal, he knew 
what would happen if somebody recorded it (which they did), and then he 
escaped punishment by claiming "it was a mistake." No, that was not a 
mistake.

And willingly getting drunk does not excuse any actions you do while drunk. 
Take responsibility as you allowed yourself to get into a state of 
intoxication in which you ought to know you do regrettable things. Its this 
reason we don't forgive drunk drivers, they must take responsibility for 
their actions, even if their actions were not that of a sober person. A 
mistake is not an acceptable excuse. 

If you want to call that a mistake, fine. But they must learn from it. But 
that should not change the fact that you must face the consequences. No 
"easing" up because you "made a mistake." No sympathy. I am basically 
saying I am sick of people doing stupid shit and then thinking they can get 
sympathy or escape judgement by calling it a "mistake." Like, a mistake is 
an error in judgement. If you don't want the consequence (eg getting 
pregnant), and you know an act (eg drinking excessively) has a foreseeably 
high chance of receiving that consequence (eg having sex while drunk is 
quite common), yet you choose to do the act anyway (drink to excess), you 
have not made an error in judgement. Unless you didn't see the link between 
drinking and pregnancy, unlikely, only then would it reasonably be called a 
mistake, as its an error in judgement because you didn't realise that the 
act (ie drinking) would likely lead to the consequence (pregnancy). And I'm 
referring to pregnancy as the consequence as the outcome, and assuming it 
was not planned.
comments.author: Goabnb94

comments.text:

consequences for certain actions, especially when using a substance with 
which they have relatively little experience? Thinking an action was less 
risky than it turned out to be is absolutely a mistake.

smarter about not getting caught." definition.

I don't appreciate when people say that Archimedes created "calculus." Yes, 
he created various methods of quadrature, but nothing on the level of 
sophistication or systemics that Newton and Leibniz developed. His methods 
were probably interesting, but what is lost is that just having calculus 
doesn't make you more advanced and doesn't give you the tools to 
necessarily advance yourself. Maybe is his quadrature and Heron's Engine 
were considered together, there might have been an advance. But one event 
does not lead to a leap in human being. Calculus helped us understand the 
heavens, but it took further developments to understand thermodynamics, 
electrodynamics, continuum dynamics, etc. and how to apply what we learned.

would have changed the world.﻿

Rod Serling of Twilight Zone fame actually wrote a lot of stories along the 
lines of trying to change the outcome of history. In his stories, often 
trying to change history either had no effect or else the consequences were 
even worse. In the case of Hitler, he was far from the only person in 
Germany who held those feelings. Anti Jewish sentiment was very strong 
there and had been for a long time. We always put a particular face to evil 
but there were MANY in Hitlers circle who were probably even more evil than 
he was. It's easier for us to cast blame on one person but that often is 
not the case where armies or governments have done horrible things. Hitler 
needed a hell of a lot of help to have Nazi plans carried out. The biggest 
problem is the old cliché of good people doing nothing, which 
allows evil to flourish.

comments.text:
+Andrew Heilborn Well of course there's no way to know what could've been… 
But you're kidding yourself if you think that the introduction (or 
lack-there-of) of calculus wouldn't've changed anything.

You said it yourself - "science travels at an exponential pace."

Now imagine where we'd be had we a couple thousand year advance on one of 
the most profound mathematical breakthroughs of our species. Just think 
about that for a while.
comments.author: TheRedButterfly

comments.text:
+SirFumblepuff So, calculus was invented two thousand years ago instead of 
five hundred. What does that do. What came as a direct result of calculus? 
No social changes, that's for sure. Perhaps it would have made Columbus a 
little more perceptive of how big around the earth was, but probably not. 
We would probably have more interesting architecture, which would be a feat 
considering how interesting it is now. But I think overall, we'd be in 
about the same place. Unfortunately science travels at an exponential pace. 
You need more pieces in place in order to make it go faster. The more 
knowledge you gain, the more you have the potential to gain. One discovery 
- which he said was merely the groundwork, not the finished product - would 
not be enough to cause a huge change. It might be enough to put us a decade 
ahead. And even then, it's hard to say what that means. 

Really the problem is that there are too many variables. No way to know 
what could have been.
comments.author: Andrew Heilborn

comments.text:
That is the saddest part of the entire video. Imagine living in a age where

comments.author: Andrew Fox

comments.text:
+SirFumblepuff Quick note, the monasteries during the Dark Ages were the 
only universities and libraries. They preserved technology and knowledge 
that, if lost, would've taken many more thousands of years to replace. 
Also, just because one person erased calculus doesn't mean we are so far 
behind. I mean, they may have understood calculus, but at the time they 
would've lacked the technology to properly utilize it, so we aren't that 
far behind because of it.
Final note; religion, just like pretty much everything else ever, isn't 
inherently bad. The people who abuse it are the bad ones. That's like 
saying science is bad because it resulted in guns and nukes. Or that space 
travel is bad because it resulted in ICBMs. Or that cars are bad because of 
drunk driving.

comments.text:
I suppose you are acting in the spirit of this video, because you are 
making a commonly repeated error.
    Just because one thing appears to be caused by another, does not 
logically lead to the conclusion that it could have *only* arisen under 
those circumstances.  In other words, there may be multiple causal pathways 
that can lead to a given effect.  Also, it is virtually impossible to prove 
that such pathways would not have occurred in other circumstances.
    As another example, this error is almost always made regarding 
government regulation.  Just because the government regulated something 
(such as air quality) and air quality improved, people say "if the gov. 
hadn't passed the Clean Air Act then we'd still be breathing 1970s levels 
of smog and having our buildings eroded by acid rain."
    This statement implies that the only way the problem of air pollution 
could ever have been addressed, was via government regulation.  This is 
false.  There are myriad ways that people in society could have dealt with 
air pollution resulting in a constructive outcome, other than by government 
regulation.
    In the case of WWII, there was enormous loss of human life, coercion of 
people into roles which they would not have otherwise chosen, as well as 
incalculable capital destruction and loss of opporunity costs.  Like the 
broken window fallacy, if you take your argument to its extreme, then if 
WWII would have never ended and just kept getting worse, we should have 
achieved immortality and the end of poverty for all by now.
    Yet that is a contradiction, because war means death and destruction of 
wealth, which means less to go around and be produced, so something is 
wrong with the argument.
In fact, it is likely that the so aforementioned positive outcomes of WWII 
would have been dwarfed by even more substantial rates of progress in 
medicine, science, and technology (with much less human suffering to 
achieve them) if WWII had never occurred at all.

comments.text:
+Neoglitch255 First of all, nowhere in the bible does it say that the Earth 
is 6000 years old, nor does it say specifically that the Earth is flat. So 
right there I can just call that you are recycling common arguments that 
you don't understand yourself. Something is not proven wrong because it is 
old, that is a logical fallacy. For example, calculus is old as well and it 
works just fine.

The 6000-year-old theory is the opinion of some people, myself not 
included, who choose to ignore very convincing scientific findings. The 
flat earth claim is also wrong, in fact in the book Job it says that the 
earth is spherical and "hangs on nothing." As for the ark, I think that 
part of the bible perhaps could *help support evolution.* Of course every 
single deviation of every single species couldn't fit on a boat that size. 
But a sample of most parts of the animal kingdom might. I can't say that I 
can explain everything, but you know neither can science explain where the 
big bang came from.

Second, I really don't want to start the whole bible vs. science debate in 
the comments section here. Again, my whole point is that science and 
religion really don't need to be seen as two contradicting entities. I 
explained what I could without being provocative, and I would appreciate 
leaving it at that with our differing opinions. I can respect that you 
don't agree with me as long as you can do the same.

comments.text:
I kinda disagree to some extent. I haven't played that game, but I think, 
by now, humans understand the importance of collaborating to meet a common 
goal during conflicts. Hence the need for alliances. And I don't mean 
people of a nation coming together, I mean nation and nation. 

If games are your thing, if you play Age of Empires, you'll see that you 
can form alliances with other teams in the game. The way I see it, there 
will always be two reasons/ways to unite: resources and land. In instances 
like WW2, there will be a small varying number of reasons to unite, such as 
to take down a tyrant like you're suggesting. 

I do agree, however, that people like Hitler are crucial to our history to 
help us learn from it.

Tl;dr: Basically, I don't think there are many reasons to unite to start 
with (by this I mean nations won't unite unless there's something to gain 
from it), so I disagree in that, in any sort of case, there aren't many 
reasons to start with. Those that do exist, however, will remain as 
constants throughout the existence of man.

top_comment.text:
It's pretty cute how this idea of killing Hitler is floating around. 
Implying, of course, that killing him would absolutely change the course of 
history. But it so happens that history is not built around CHARACTERS. 
Well, not as much as we tend to believe. Rather, it is built around 
PRINCIPLES, TENDENCIES, and CONTEXTS. A country with deep economic 
troubles, hyperinflation, and lots of resentment, is almost certain to 
produce a dictator. And dictatorship is almost certain to rely on finding 
internal and external "enemies" to justify the current troubles.

My point is: even if, by some super-dooper-lucky chance Hitler had been 
killed, there were plenty of people to replace him in that political 
context. Just look at Hitler's immediate surrounding. 

And have you considered the possibility that we might, in fact, be 
extremely lucky? That someone, a person who could have become an even more 
terrifying figure in history, more talented and successful leader than 
Hitler, a person who could have won WW II for Nazi Germany, was actually 
killed in WW I? And Hitler was, if you please, only a second "best"? How 
about this?﻿

comments.text:
+TinyShaman Hitler was able to lead germany to another war mainly because 
the german people felt unfairly treated and unfairly depicted as the main 
culprit of ww1. Germanys people might have accepted a dictatorship with 
another leader (like italy or russia), but it most likely wouldn't have 
lead to a war of this extent. I wouldn't say that the people at that time 
were especially to keen to attack all its surrounding countries and kill 
jews, however im neither a historian nor have lived back then. It were 
partly the convincing and empowering speeches of their leader. I'm not 
trying to justify ww2 or unburden the germans at that time, but I think 
that Hitler had very big influence in the way the people thought. He used 
their general unhappiness with the outcome of ww1 to turn them against jews 
and other nations and accept war as something honorable. Also without 
Hitler as leader some extreme decisions wouldn't have been made, because a 
different leader would've been more humane. This might have changed the 
outcome or even the start of ww2 in both ways. I'm pretty sure though, that 
Hitler has not done all by himself. He was the face that was needed to 
convince a nation, but Goebbels who wrote his speeches, his assistants and 
officers did most of the crucial job for planning the leadership and the 
war. So the question whether it would've came to ww2 without Hitler is 
tricky, and no one will ever be able to answer it.

top_comment.text:
Hey Vsauce, I have a question:
If you placed a peanut and a watermelon next to each other, how long would 
it take for the watermelons gravitational pull to pull the peanut to it?﻿
top_comment.author: Reel Hawkins

comments.text:
You CAN calculate it in space using three formulas. I'm lazy to do it, but 
I'll write them for you.

- The formula to calculate the gravitational force: 
F=6,67*(10^-11)*m1*m2/(r^2)
F: The gravitational force, which you will need (and it is in newton, i 
just simplified the formula, but the calculation is still correct. You just 
have to remember it's in Newton)
m1: The mass of the watermelon
m2: The mass of the peanut
r: The distance between the watermelon and the peanut.
You need to make up the last three data to go on.
(FYI: r^2 means r*r; 10^-11 means 1/(10*10*10*...)

- The formula calculate the acceleration in both the peanut and watermelon:
a=F/m
You have to calculate the acceleration of both.
a: Acceleration
F: The gravitational force
m: Mass

- The formula to calculate the time needed for them to meet (requires some 
logic and math skills)
s=(t^2)*a/2
You have to calculate the time for both.
s: The path an object moves. Keep in mind that the sum of the two paths 
equals to r, the distance of the objects.
t: The time it takes. This one is equal in both object's formula. (it takes 
the same amount of time for the peanut to reach the watermelon, than it 
takes for the watermelon to reach the peanut).
a: The acceleration. You calculated both object's acceleration before.

Trust me, i'm in an engineer college. :D I'd say it takes a long time even 
in space, when the distance is like only 1m.

equations for that! You need the masses of the two objects, m(watermelon) 
and m(peanut), then you need the distance between the two objects (r), and 
Newton's handy dandy Universal Gravity Constant, G, with a value of 6.6726 
x 10-11N-m2/kg2.
Nest step, plug it into the formula:
F = G * m1 * m2 / r^ 2
In words, G is equal to 6.6726 times 10 to the -11 power in units of 
Newtons times meters squared per kilogram squared.

Say you've got a 9 kg watermelon, a .001 kg peanut, and a meter (.001 km) 
between them. Do some calculations, and F = 0.61E -11 Netwons
comments.author: TheSocialIrony

And think of it this way: Many of the reasons Hitler was unsuccessful were 
the ideas and changes he made to different plans. For example, when he 
changed his targets for the aerial fights in the UK to civilian, he caused 
more deaths but those deaths weren't so useful, since he ceased bombing 
actual military installations.

When he had soldiers stay back from Normandy, thinking there was going to 
be an attack elsewhere, he made it easier for the Normandy invasion to be 
successful due to fewer troops to hold back the assault.

And most importantly, when he chose to turn on the USSR, he created the 
same problem that killed the Central Powers of WW1. A war on two fronts, 
and even when he was successfully fighting the Russians he took a page from 
Napoleon's book of "how not to invade Russia" and got caught in the 
wintertime.

My personal thoughts are that the Nazis would've still rose to power, Still 
would've attacked the rest of the world, and still would've attacked in 
blitzkrieg style. However, they could've had a more competent leader, and 
that could've spelled much more doom and death upon the world, whether they 
won or lost.

comments.text:
There's this old debate in philosophy regarding counterfactual statements. 
Counterfactuals are claims about what would have happened instead if we 
changed some fact about the world.

And so the debate's about Julius Caesar and the Korean war. Let's say 
Julius Ceaser had been a commander during the Korean war. What kind of 
weapons would he have used?

Well, some say he would have used catapults, because after all, that's the 
kind of weapon Julius Caesar usually made use of.
Others say Julius Caesar would obviously have used nuclear bombs, because 
after all, he was a ruthless war-chief, who always used the most powerful 
weapons available to him.

The real philosophical debate isn't really about Ceasar, but about whether 
any such claims are true or false and how we should decide between them.
comments.author: DisThoughts

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce.
Michael here. The title of this video is misspelled
in honour of mistakes. Mistakes are
everywhere, they surround us like air
To err is human. Faults, flaws, faux pas, fumbles
and fallacies are as much a part of who we are today
as the stuff we've gotten right. For instance,
if a knight knocked your knuckle or knifed your knee,
why would there be so many "k"s?
Well, the "k"s are silent by mistake.

The original old English forms of these
words were pronounced with "k"
sounds.
K-nife, k-night, k-nee.

But that's a bit of a mouthful to say and
because reading and writing weren't as
common hundreds of years ago,

people just pronounced words the way
they want to do, regardless of spelling.

Spelling is fun. Warren G knows what
I'm talking about. In the fourth
verse of his "What's Next", he asks what's next.
What's next, what's N-X-E-T
Spelling isn't the only thing
we get wrong. The history of science is a graveyard

of dead an abandoned ideas.
Fritz Machlup coined the phrase

"Half-life of knowledge". The amount of time
it takes for half of the knowledge
within a field

to be superseded by new, better ideas
or to simply be shown
untrue. Donald Hebb famously
estimated that the half-life of knowledge in psychology
is just five years.

Humans are awesome, don't get me wrong,
but we tend to believe that what we currently
think we know about the universe
is reasonably correct, even though statistics
aren't on our side. Previous generations

incorrectly thought the exact same thing
about what they used to think was true.

My favourite examples of the ubiquity
of mistakes are production
errors in popular songs. They're like

humbling Easter eggs, just waiting
to be found. For instance,
Buffalo Springfield's "For What It's Worth".
26 second in the "be" in the lyric
"beware" is clipped, as is the "p"
in "people" at 1:24 minute. Once you hear the mistake,
it's tough to unhear it. In "Hey Jude"

Paul McCartney misses a cord. And if you
listen closely you can clearly hear him
say
"F***ing h*ll". Seriously, it's in the actual song.

Go listen to it. In fact, there's an entire
website that chronicles
mistakes in Beatles' songs. Take a look at this
700-year-old prayer book. A monk
wrote it on fresh, clean paper.

I'm kidding, of course. He scraped the ink
off an older manuscript, cut the pages and
rotated them before
writing all over them. A mistake? Well,
kind of. Recent multispectral images

of the prayer book have revealed that
the old manuscript he
erased was a previously unknown copy of a work
by Archimedes. It was called "The Method"
and laid out the heart of calculus thousands of years
before Newton and Leibniz. If that one monk
hadn't erased that one book, would we be

hundreds, thousands of years
mathematically and technologically more
advanced today
than we currently are? It's hard to say.

All that is certain is that we would
continue to make ridiculous mistakes,
like

the Mars Climate Orbiter.
This 327.6 million dollar expedition
burned up in the red planet's atmosphere because

when calculating flight manoeuvres NASA
used the agreed-upon metric units
while Lockheed Martin used the imperial system.
This is Neil Armstrong taking humankind's first steps
on the Moon. It's about the best footage

we have. The original tapes containing
the highest quality recording
of that moment have been lost. They were probably
recorded over by later test missions. Ten years ago
Sergio Martinez became lost in the woods while

hunting outside of San Diego.
Hoping to attract the attention of
rescuers, he lit a small fire.

But that fire quickly got out of control
and became a giant Cedar Fire.
It destroyed 300,000 acres of land,
2,322 homes and killed
15 people.

The man carrying a wounded soldier in
this painting, based on a photograph
taken during World War I,

is Henry Tandey, an English recipient
of the Victoria Cross.

Four years after the event in this image
Tandey caught a wounded

German soldier in his gun sights.
But rather than kill the man,

Tandey took pity on his wounded state
and spared his life.
The German he allowed to live was

this man. Later the man whose life he
spared wore his mustache
shorter but still had the same name,
Adolf Hitler. In 1918

did Henry Tandey miss a chance to kill
Hitler? Detailed researchers found that
the exact

days their units were in the same
location don't quite match up.
The story is apocryphal but what is known
is that Hitler owned a copy of the painting
of Tandey, and in 1938,

when meeting with Neville Chamberlain,
Hitler pointed to Tandey

and told Chamberlain: "That man came
so close to killing me

in 1918 that I thought I
should never see Germany
again." So, who's wrong?
Maybe Hitler confirmed the story

merely because he hoped to make up extra
evidence that providence had kept him
alive to pursue his goals.
Either way, someone
is mistaken. Missed opportunities

are a bummer.
Obsessing over them is not healthy but regret
is a powerful emotion. How do you deal
with regret, with guilt?

Can you? In the early morning hours on a
bench outside a hotel in Anaheim this
summer

Ze Frank told me something
I am going to paraphrase.
I love this metaphor. Stuff in your past
is like a carving on the bark of sapling. Over time,
the scar, the carving won't go away.

Because of the way trees grow it won't
go up or down much either, it'll just
stay right where it began. It might even get darker.
But it won't get bigger. You, however,

can. You can keep growing,
doing more things, more branches,

being more things. The wound won't get
smaller but you can make it a smaller
part
of who you are. Maybe regrets
are like that. They stick around forever
like arborglyphs. Or maybe they make like a tree
and leaf.

A red or purple leaf in the autumn.
As days get shorter
and chlorophyll production decreases, the yellow
and orange carotenoids, which are always in leaves,

appear as the green fades.
But red and purple leaves

are the interesting ones.
As winter approaches it would seem to be a good
time for trees to conserve energy but some trees
do the opposite. Instead of giving up, they spend
extra energy producing anthocyanins
to turn their leaves red and purple hues.

These colours protect their leaves from
sun damage before their nutrients can
all be

used and may also be a defence
against insects looking for

a parasitic home.
A way for the tree to tell the insects: "Yes,
I am in part dying but not without a fight.
I am still very much vital."
Drought and even turn a kit applied by man

can bring about these colors prematurely.
When you look at beautiful
autumn colours, you are looking at stress.

But the bigger the fight the trees
put up, the more energy

they put into their defences at the
very end, the more brilliant
their colours will be. Winter
will eventually come. But scientifically,
the brightest, deepest, most remarkable colours
